Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Species delimitation, speciation, and evolution of the niche in slimy salamanders (Plethodontidae: Plethodon)
Award.AbstractNarration:
This research will examine geographic patterns of variation in DNA sequences to delimit species in a widespread group of eastern North American salamanders (the Plethodon glutinosus group). These salamanders are often the most abundant vertebrates in forested habitats and play a key role in ecosystem functioning. However, due to their overall similarity in appearance and ecology, identifying the number of species in the group has been problematic. The investigators will use a novel combination of genetic, physiological, and microclimatic data to discover species, and to explore the roles that stasis and divergence in the ecological niche play in the origin and maintenance of species lineages.

Understanding the role that the ecological niche plays in generating and maintaining species boundaries will advance our knowledge of how species will respond to rapid changes in climate. Resolving uncertainty surrounding the species-level taxonomy of the Plethodon glutinosus group will have immediate conservation implications in rapidly developing regions of the southeastern United States. In addition, the proposed research will provide training in evolution, ecology, and conservation biology for a postdoctoral student, two graduate students, and several undergraduate researchers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major objectives of this project were to (1) develop a set of evolutionary relationships and taxonomy for the Plethodon glutinosus species group, (2) to examine the role of the environmental requirements of species in speciation by developing species-specific distribution models based on the measured functional capacities of species, and (3) to explore the utility of alternative distribution models for delimiting species and studying the ecology of speciation. In order to examine the role of the environment in speciation, one requires a spatial representation of the fundamental niche. I accomplished this by developing a spatially explicit, physiologically-structured mechanistic species distribution model that is extendable to all species within the P. glutinosus species group provided certain physiological data are available. This model has been validated and used to determine the physiological and ecological factors that drive the formation of species range limits in eastern North American species of Plethodon. Upon completing this model, we have begun evaluating important elements in the models (i.e., species’ physiological traits) and exploring their role in driving broader spatial patters of species distributions.

 

To date we have demonstrated that the species distribution models developed during the grant funding period perform well and accurately predict the known geographic distributions of several species in the P. glutinosus species group (particularly the montane endemic species). We have also demonstrated that these models can be extended to incorporate species interactions to determine the relative influence of physiological constraints and species interactions in structuring species distributions along mountain slopes. Thus, we now have a working modeling framework available to address one of the major objectives of this larger project (i.e., determining the role of the environment in speciation). Other recent work funded by this grant tested hypotheses about the constancy of the relationship between metabolic rate and body mass and tested general predictions of the Metabolic Theory of Ecology. This grant supported research testing whether salamanders have the capacity to acclimate physiological performance to variation in temperature. We completed several projects examining individual variation in physiological and behavioral traits in salamanders. Specifically, we tested whether variation in the thermal sensitivity of standard metabolic rate was significantly correlated with the thermal sensitivity of maximal metabolic rates, at the individual level. This is the first test of this hypothesis. We found significant individual variation in thermal sensitivity of both standard and maximal metabolic rates, and significant correlations between the two. We also completed a project assessing the relationships between standard metabolic rate, feeding rate, and voluntary behavior among individual salamanders. Finally, we completed a project demonstrating significant variation in evaporative water loss rates among salamander populations along a mountain slope. This latter project demonstrates that local adaptation to prevailing conditions of cutaneous resistance to evaporation. This result runs counter to the prevailing wisdom of salamander water loss.

 

This project has provided training and opportunities for research to three undergraduate students; two of whom were supported by NSF REU supplements. The project has also provided research opportunities for three graduate students. Two of these students completed Masters theses associated with this work and both of them are currently enrolled in excellent PhD programs in similar fields.
